Experimentation is always encouraged! That being said, here are some tips on how to use these plugins and techniques effectively:

1. Use stereo imaging tools sparingly: Adding too much stereo spread to a mix can result in it sounding thin and disconnected. Start with small adjustments and listen carefully to find the right balance between width and clarity.

2. Focus on the mid-range: Widening the stereo field in the mid-range frequencies can help make vocals, guitars, and other instruments sound wider and add space to the mix.

3. Avoid widening bass frequencies: Bass frequencies are typically kept centered so that they don't lose their impact and can be precisely balanced with the kick drum. Avoid widening these frequencies.

4. Experiment with panning: Panning is one of the most effective ways to create a stereo image within a mix, so try different panning techniques to find what works best.

5. Be aware of mono compatibility: Remember that not every listener will hear the mix in stereo. Make sure important elements of the mix, like bass and drums, still sound good when played through a single speaker.

By experimenting with these plugins and techniques while keeping these tips in mind, you can find new and creative ways to enhance the stereo image of your mixes and create a more immersive listening experience for your audience.
